item.title: By: Sharad Goel
item.dc:creator: Sharad Goel
item.description: Ah, I understand the confusion. Yes, I'm talking about a situation in which you're interested in <strong>repeatedly</strong> generating 50-50 outcomes, not just a single fair coin flip.
item.content:encoded: Ah, I understand the confusion. Yes, I’m talking about a situation in which you’re interested in repeatedly generating 50-50 outcomes, not just a single fair coin flip.

item.title: By: Lev Reyzin
item.dc:creator: Lev Reyzin
item.description: Sharad -- I don't get it. Once you have any die land on different numbers, you're done (High->Low=Tails; Low->High=Heads). Is the MAB problem you set up to learn over time (ie. needing a fair coin many times) which coin is best?
item.content:encoded: Sharad — I don’t get it. Once you have any die land on different numbers, you’re done (High->Low=Tails; Low->High=Heads). Is the MAB problem you set up to learn over time (ie. needing a fair coin many times) which coin is best?

item.title: By: Sharad Goel
item.dc:creator: Sharad Goel
item.description: Lev: for two rolls of the same die the payoff is 0 if they land on the same number, and 1 otherwise. Then the expected reward is the probability that the die results in distinct numbers on successive rolls (i.e., the probability that you can assert 'heads' or 'tails').
item.content:encoded: Lev: for two rolls of the same die the payoff is 0 if they land on the same number, and 1 otherwise. Then the expected reward is the probability that the die results in distinct numbers on successive rolls (i.e., the probability that you can assert ‘heads’ or ‘tails’).

item.title: By: Lev Reyzin
item.dc:creator: Lev Reyzin
item.description: Sharad - what are the payoffs in this bandit problem?
item.content:encoded: Sharad – what are the payoffs in this bandit problem?

item.title: By: Cris Iconomu
item.dc:creator: Cris Iconomu
item.description: use new rules: - the face "facing" the thrower is the one that counts. - if the die is pointing an edge at the thrower, use a ruler or something similar to push it agains the wall and force it to present a face (okay, this is a bit streched but you get the idea...) no matter how the dice are loaded, by disregarding which face is up you eliminate the one factor participating in the "mechanism" - gravity. the rest is just ... random i asumed the use of cubic dice :)
item.content:encoded:
use new rules:
– the face “facing” the thrower is the one that counts.
– if the die is pointing an edge at the thrower, use a ruler or something similar to push it agains the wall and force it to present a face (okay, this is a bit streched but you get the idea…)
no matter how the dice are loaded, by disregarding which face is up you eliminate the one factor participating in the “mechanism” – gravity. the rest is just … random
i asumed the use of cubic dice :)

item.title: By: Sharad Goel
item.dc:creator: Sharad Goel
item.description: Alex, I admit that it's a subjective call, and really, the two solutions are nearly identical. As an aside, if your goal is to efficiently generate 50-50 outcomes, instead of alternating between coins you could treat the situation as a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-armed_bandit" rel="nofollow">multi-armed bandit</a>, learning over time the better coin to flip.
item.content:encoded: Alex, I admit that it’s a subjective call, and really, the two solutions are nearly identical. As an aside, if your goal is to efficiently generate 50-50 outcomes, instead of alternating between coins you could treat the situation as a multi-armed bandit, learning over time the better coin to flip.

item.title: By: Alex Strehl
item.dc:creator: Alex Strehl
item.description: fwiw, I still like my answer better than Bill's, because it requires less rolls on average to halt (even if you're required to roll both dice each turn).
item.content:encoded: fwiw, I still like my answer better than Bill’s, because it requires less rolls on average to halt (even if you’re required to roll both dice each turn).
